text:
People of BinaryBuilder...
I'm confused with one thing...
Musl C and glib C....
If both compile for the same architecture.... example x86_64 linux
Wouldn't the binary created by both musl C and glib C, run in that architecture
They're just different libc implementations, not compilers.....

Why compile with both musl C and glibc?

elements.text:

If both compile for the same architecture.... example x86_64 linux
Wouldn't the binary created by both musl C and glib C, run in that architecture
They're just different libc implementations, not compilers.....

Why compile with both musl C and glibc?

text:
> Why compile with both musl C and glibc in the first place?
because they're different and some users may want to run Julia in musl-based systems

elements.text: Why compile with both musl C and glibc in the first place?
because they're different and some users may want to run Julia in musl-based systems

text:
Hmmm...
We just need the binary to run on that architecture right?
If we use glibc implementation to create the binary for a specific platform, or just use muslc to build for that platform, wouldn't the binary made by either, just work on that platform?
Why use muslc and glibc at the same time?

elements.text:
Hmmm...
We just need the binary to run on that architecture right?
If we use glibc implementation to create the binary for a specific platform, or just use muslc to build for that platform, wouldn't the binary made by either, just work on that platform?
Why use muslc and glibc at the same time?

text: I mean, binary itself is something on a machine level right?

elements.text: I mean, binary itself is something on a machine level right?

text:
Assume I'm using
glibc to compile for a platform W, it outputs a binary called gw
musl to compile for a platform W, it outputs a binary called mw
If `./gw` and `./mw`, both work on W, isn't one of gw or mw enough? Why do we need to build both of them....? What are the consequences of using ./gw on aarch64 Alpine Linux?
